verses.text: LORD, how many are my foes! Many rise up against me.
verses.comment: David cries out to God during intense opposition, traditionally seen as when he fled from Absalom (see 2 Samuel 15:12). In Christian tradition, Psalm 3 prefigures the suffering of Christ surrounded by enemies before His victory. The rising of many against David recalls the spiritual warfare faced by believers and Christ Himself.

verses.text: Many say of me, 'There is no salvation for him in God.'
verses.comment: David's enemies doubt God's willingness or ability to save him. This echoes mockery faced by Christ on the cross (Matthew 27:43), showing a deeper spiritual meaning: True deliverance comes from God's faithfulness, regardless of the world's doubts.

verses.text: But you, LORD, are a shield around me, my glory, and the lifter of my head.
verses.comment: God is depicted as protector, source of honor, and restorer. The language of 'shield' signifies God's intimate care (see Ps. 28:7). The lifting of the head hints at resurrection and restoration—a shadow of how Christ was raised and glorified after humiliation.

verses.text: I call out to the LORD, and he answers me from his holy mountain.
verses.comment: The 'holy mountain' refers to Zion, a symbol of God's presence and kingship (Ps. 2:6). David’s confidence in God answering prayer from his sanctuary foreshadows the Christian understanding of intercession and authoritative mediation from God's dwelling place.

verses.text: I lie down and sleep; I awaken, for the LORD sustains me.
verses.comment: Despite danger, David finds peace through trust in God's sustaining power. Sleep and waking serve as metaphors for death and resurrection, a theme fulfilled in Jesus’ death and rising from the grave, and spiritually in the believer’s hope.

verses.text: I will not fear even though tens of thousands stand against me on every side.
verses.comment: Faith in God removes fear regardless of circumstances. The courage expressed here is mirrored in the confidence of Christ facing opposition, and is commended to all believers as a trust rooted in God’s sovereign protection.

verses.text: Arise, LORD! Save me, my God! For you strike all my enemies on the cheek; you break the teeth of the wicked.
verses.comment: The plea for God's intervention reflects His role as divine judge, enacting justice against wickedness. This language points toward ultimate victory over evil, and the spiritual defeat of adversaries through divine power. The phrase 'break the teeth' symbolizes total disarmament of evil.

verses.text: Salvation belongs to the LORD; your blessing is upon your people.
verses.comment: Here salvation is affirmed as exclusive to God, and His blessing upon the chosen people is proclaimed. This verse is foundational for understanding the role of divine grace, God's initiative in salvation, and how blessing comes through belonging to the community chosen by God—prefiguring the Church as the vessel of grace.
